title: Desktop Rotatable iPhone + Apple Watch Stand

description.text:
https://youtu.be/l5Ui0pF16ps

This version of my phone desk stand has a spot for an Apple Watch to charge behind the phone. You MUST download the related set of things, which actually holds the phone. The system is modular, so you can size the phone holder for your exact phone case:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:878682

This is just one of a set of device holders I'm gradually accumulating. The link above will be the clearinghouse for the set.

Assembly is straightforward. There are 3 pieces which should just snap together, though it may be a bit stiff the first time.

This is only 1 of the 3 pieces, you will also need to download the set here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:878682

Notes:

  • Suggest a high infill to give it some mass so it doesn't slide around too much.

  • Pretty much any plastic seems to work well. I've tried PLA and PETC (with a couple of pieces in ABS).

  • I've printed this with as large as a 0.75mm nozzle and a 0.5mm step. However, even though it's a "bulk" piece, there are a few small details which come out much better with a finer step and smaller nozzle. This will take several hours to print, even on a pretty fast printer.

  • If the little lump on the surface of the stand itself doesn't print well, you may be able to drill it out and replace it with small piece of smoothed wire, a small bearing or similar. The lack of this piece will simply mean the holder won't lock well at 90 degree increments.

  • Generally if you need to take it apart, you can probably just give it a firm pull. If the latch mechanism gets stuck, there is a small hole about paper-clip size near the end of the barrel on one side. If you push there (with a paper clip), you should be able to disengage the latch.

  • I haven't found it necessary to use the screw-holes on the phone holder piece to latch the phone in place. Gravity does a nice job. If your cable is torquing your phone and it won't stay in place, you can print out 3-5 of the optional latch pieces and screw them into the holder so they can be rotated. Alternatively, you can screw a rubber grommet into each spot.

BEAR DOWN!!
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fzjwCnhK3iB

I've made this little thingy to allow constant angle sharpening on Spyderco double stuff sharpener. It has set angle of 15 deg, with knife's grind it should give ~20 degrees per side which I consider best for retouching Your blade (and fastest), just like Your triangle sharpener is designed to work.

You basically snap it onto double stuff, index Your knife and follow this angle. It's not intended to slide entire thingy as it will clog Your sharpener. It makes sure You always start honing at the right angle, and is small and light enough to have it always with sharpener.

I've also made some variations of it:
-Slider thats designed to be sled with a knife (is taller than sharpener just slightly so it does not clog it)
-Version with integrated vertical stand to work like with sharpmaker
Best way to print this thing is giving 100% infill and printing upside-down. It's very tight tolerance so You might have to scale it up 1-2% for shrinkage.

title: Limestone Indian Warrior Bas Relief Panel

description.text:
This limestone panel of a Native American Warrior is the mate to the Native American Maiden, both of which are mounted by the Phillips Avenue entrance to the First National Bank Building.

Like his mate, he and the nearby limestone eagle are the sole survivors of the former 1920s bank building decor. During the push for urban renewal that swept America in the 1950s-1970s, anything old-fashioned was deemed unworthy of being saved and met an ignominious end with a wrecking ball. Fortunately, these limestone panels and sculpture were saved.

The warrior and his maiden are a popular spot for people to pose with.

author: jerry7171

description.text:
A 3-axis drawing robot!

Parts:
1 - xstage029.stl
1 - zgear029.stl
1 - zrack029.stl
1 - xrack029.stl
1 - yrack030.stl
2 - Pen_Arm_Plotter.stl
2 - Plotter_XY_Gear.stl
1 - Zip Tie
3 - 9g micro servo motors
2 - Small screws
2 - hex nuts for screws
Superglue
Arduino or similar

Software: Arduino ide https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software
Processing https://processing.org/download/
Inkscape https://inkscape.org/en/
Inkscape extension https://github.com/martymcguire/inkscape-unicorn

Assemble using instructions at http://plotterbot.com/2013/12/how-to-build-a-tiny-3-axis-cnc-drawing-robot/.

Since the instructions are for version 0.29 and you printed 0.30, you will need to make the following changes:
The pen plotter arm will plug into the holes on the Z axis. Put one at the top, and another at the bottom. Look at the picture above. Secure the plotter arms in the z rack with a drop of superglue each.

Use the cross-shaped head that comes with the stepper motors, put the gear on the cross-shaped head, and screw it in. You don't need to use the rubber gaskets.

Attach the Z-axis motor to pin 13, the Y-axis motor to pin 12, and the X-axis motor to pin 11 on your arduino.

I put an AA battery on the gantry for counterbalance so the bot doesn't tip over when the y-axis is extended.

Use the Software guide here: http://plotterbot.com/tiny-cnc/challenges-entered/drawing-robot-afron-ultra-affordable-educational-robot-2013-design-challenge-entry/tinycnc-drawing-robot-software-user-guide/

In Inkscape, make your document be 6" by 4". Only draw in the right upper quadrant. The other quadrants have negative coordinates and will not translate with the processing sketch. Read the instructions referenced above to make sure you have a drawing that will convert well to gcode. Save As... gcode, and remember the file name.

Load the arduino sketch to your bot.

Load the processing sketch. Change the file name to the file name of your gcode in two places. Run the processing sketch... and it should draw.

Things that need to be fixed:
Decrease the play in the axes
Keep the gantry from popping out of the x rack
Better counterbalance
Better software

title: Nylon roller 4-wheel carriage with eccentric spacers and Rostock printed u-joints

description.text:
These are carriages with eccentric spacers (inspired by the eccentric spacers Openbuilds uses) that can be customized for whatever rollers you can find, with a GT2 belt clamp and Rostock's printed u-joints.

Cautionary tale: If your carriage doesn't move smoothly up and down, it could be due to your wheels being oval, which would cause your layers to shift with a period of half of the wheel circumference.

1. Print 1 carriage and 4 eccentric spacers.
  2. Stick the eccentric spacers into the carriage holes
  3. Thread the assembly with wheel through with washers in this order:
    • M5 bolt
    • M5 washer
    • Carriage
    • Spacer
    • M5 washer
    • Wheel
    • M5 washer
    • M5 nut

Adjust the carriage tightness by twisting the eccentric spacers. To keep the carriage center, you need to tweak the eccentric spacers in tandem with their opposite side. The spacers have a triangle on the outside indicating the direction of eccentricity.

If possible, look for double-bearing wheels. Mine are nylon-wheels glued onto single bearings, and they deflect a bit when force is exerted on them.

Update (8/7/2015):
Thickened carriage, filleted arms, and added a screw belt tensioner.

This is a simple panel for making an LED light for filming. Back has a GoPro compatable mount that is a snug fit so you may need to sand it to get the fit your after.

description.text:
This is an aid to make it easier to calibrate the x & y axes of your 3D printer.  
Using calipers to calibrate the x & y axes was a big chore for me since I could never seem to get consistent reference points on the carriage & frame to make measurements.  I was resorting to taking several measurements (invariably all would turn out slightly different), and then average the results.  
This thing is just a simple pointer that you can clip to the carriage.  The pdf file is a mm graph that you lay on the bed.  
11-23-13 Update:  Made a revised .stl file with a built-in "clip" (meant to mount on a 6 mm thick extruder support).  Also made the pointer multiaxis so you can measure both x and y axes without having to move the pointer

Make a paper print of the mm graph pdf file.  Make sure the "Actual size" box is checked in the Adobe Acrobat Print menu size options when you print it out.  Measure the graph with a mm ruler to make sure it is accurate.  
Print the pointer with your 3D printer.  Size/settings are not critical, except you will want the tip to be as sharp as possible.  Clip the pointer to a convenient place on your carriage and lower the z axis so the pointer tip is just above the bed.  Lay the graph on the bed and adjust its position so the pointer tip is at the "0" mark, and the pointer tip moves straight along the axis line on the graph.  Clip the graph to the bed so it doesn't move.  Now just use your printer interface program (e.g. pronterface) to move the carriage 10 mm at a time - the graph will show you how far the carriage is actually moving.  The graph is divided in 0.5 mm increments between 40 and 60 mm, and between 90 and 110 to allow you to fine tune the measurements at those distances.  It is possible to estimate values in between the 0.5 mm marks (it may help if you file the pointer tip sharper in order to do this).  The difference between how far the carriage is supposed to move vs how far it actually moves will allow you to calculate the calibration value.  Repeat for the y axis.

comments.text: Yes that is true - but the graph I made is divided at 0.5 mm intervals between 40 - 60, and 90 - 110.  When you're trying to calibrate your x-y axes to submillimeter accuracy it helps to get as fine a resolution as you can.  I'm not sure you can get ready-made graph paper with 0.5 mm divisions.
comments.author: poboy

comments.text: You don't need a well calibrated printer, there is loads of paper with printed grid (by means of 1 mm grid). Even A4 paper! So, there is no need to print anything :D And the cost of the paper is almost nothing...
comments.author: deviant

comments.text: Irony.. You have to have a reasonably calibrated printer to print the tool to help you calibrate ;) J/K
comments.author: HarshReality

comments.text: The dimensions of the pointer are not critical - it is basically a tip that moves with the carriage.  You could clip say a pushpin to the carriage and that would suffice (actually would be better since that's a really sharp point!)
comments.author: HarshReality

comments.text:
Come to think of it, you could just use a mm ruler directly on the bed. I just like to torture myself by creating unnecessary things I guess :P
[Actually my ruler is stainless steel & I have a hard time seeing the marks. The high contrast of a printout is a lot easier for me to see.]
comments.author: poboy

author: thebigguy62

description.text: Pendaglio
Fiore da infilare su biro o matita

Coccodrillo con nome. Modifica il nome con tinkercad.
https://tinkercad.com/things/9xjzOPxH92V

This is a traditional dancing toy, printed in one.go. The joints are very loose so that it moves freely.

I have made a few improvements in JigDoll5-Heel. The main change was to add a heel to the foot so he could do some of the clever tricks Jeff Warner shows online. Sadly it doesn't really work - it needs a radical change of shape, and I quite like his big feet.

To use it, you'll need a springy board and some 9mm dowel (fettled a little for a good fit). Search online for film of them in the hands of good players.

In Faberdashery's Orange Juice pla it looks like a cheese flavoured potato snack . . . a dancing cheese flavoured potato snack.

Jig-Dolls were widespread in the UK and parts of the USA. Kids love them and they make everyone smile, but they can easily steal the attention from a great musical performance, so use them sensitively.

Traditionally they are given a name. This is version 5, so a name beginning with "V" would be nice (Keep "Vi..." names for version 6).

This is a single print, so should be straightforward.

It needs to be removed carefully so as not to break the joints.

The upper arm flange is added to stop the pieces lifting during the print.

My printer seems temperamental about this design, will fail 8 prints in a row, then suddenly start behaving. I think it is to do with the phase of the moon.

author: ozanbdr

description.text:
Just a simple box!

After i saw the box made by Erik Boese on Thinkercad (https://tinkercad.com/things/7WO02UX5Pxg) I decided to create my own only with sligtly thinner bottom and with more height.

Made with Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/things/cgOJeDmUR8G
I printed my box with the Robox printer. No support needed.

comments.text:
I made one in openScad that is customizable a couple of years ago. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:189264
You can put text on the top too. Just tooting my own horn! ;)

X-trude combines all flexibility in filament-diameter and is bowden and wades-extruder in one!

I will also integrate a justable height setting in Hot-End, so you can easily set optimal first start-layer height on bed.

4 plastic parts are necessary for X-trude - construction is now done.
I will make a prototype soon to check the function.

title: DaVaHaG verion 2 - Dynamic Variable Hand Grip tension box for e-NABLE raptor hand

description.text:
Here is version 2 of the variable hand grip tensioning box that I am developing for the e-NABLE Raptor type hands.
Here is a video of this hand in action:
https://youtu.be/oHB3XCw9yUs

Please see the following link for information on version 1 that I reference in this video:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:890953

This version is half the height of version 1 with the same effective action. 2 of the original cams has been placed side by side and 180 out of phase to each other. The finger strings run under the first cam and over the second cam. The knob is connected to the 2 cams via gears to allow the cams to be placed into 4 unique positions to cause the 4 different grips.

comments.text: How in the world do you print these gears out. Can I get a version with support already added? Thanks.
comments.author: johnp125

comments.text: The gear with knob is printed with the knob side down.  No supports.  The cam piece is printed with the lobes of the cams vertical to cause the layers to run through the length of the part to strengthen it.  The bottom side of the part oriented so that the point on the part where all 4 cams are the tallest are pointing straight down.  Supports then are used.  What program are you using to slice and I'll try to make a version with supports?

author: Vasilpap

description.text:
When the speed is not all.
When you win not because you are first.
This is when MetalSlug 250 FPV Racer is needed.

Heavy, bulky but cutie little FPV Racer.

Motor tube are 10mm diameter 180mm long.
Glued in place with fluid cyano.

On bottom a vented chamber for 4 ESC.
On middle a chamber for Naze32 or CC3D.
Top bay for 3S2200 zippy battery.

Added up-right motor pod for 30mm diameter motors.
Added up-right motor pod for 30mm diameter motors 10° tilted that allow 6" props.

MK2 Fuselage incorporate some modification from MK1 experience, removed internal carbon plate and all screws. Now motor tubes must be glued with fluid cyano to one semi fuselage. The other semi fuselage will be held in place by friction and battery straps. Added a CC3D plate from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:95644 with CC3D 90° rotated.

I'm building it with MK1 fuselage (because already printed) and new upright motor PODs.

The motors are Mystery A2208-14 1450Kv that I already have.
At 3S it will need 6" props.
May be a faster motor is better.

The electronic bay is too small, I have to bend the ESC connectors on CC3D to clean the ceiling.

Printed in PLA (E-SUN HobbyKing)
0.5mm nozzle.
0.4mm layers
225° print
Support needed because of hollow fuselage.
The fuselage is not tight but Cura handles it well.

After print the axis holes on fuselage must be drilled with a 10mm drill running backward (otherwise it will crack the PLA)
When the axis slides with few friction, close the fuselage with the carbon plate in place and drill the 3mm holes for M3 screw holding all together.
The four M3 nuts will be glued in place in some ways.

Motor pod must also be drilled with 10mm revers running drill.
They must be glued in place using the flat part on pod to align them.

comments.text: I am awaiting new filament to start print but, the motors you are using are no good. Would suggest 2204 2300kv on 6 inch props, these will work well. Size is very good and allows me to play with length of carbon tube plus, possibility for tilt control on motors. Will post photos as I start building, thanks for a great design.

title: Third hand PCB vise with ball joint

description.text: Derivative of "Vise Left" with a ball joint to replace the magnifying lens of Radio Shack's Helping Hands: http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=3928375

• I printed with external support turned on, which only prints under the shaft and ball joint. Easily cleaned off with a knife and file.
  • I used 1/4" rod, so I bored out the pair of holes for that with a 1/4" drill bit by hand, mounting the bit in my cordless drill and rotating the part by hand around the bit.
  • I then widened the holes with a small hobby file until the part slid easily on the rod.
  • I mounted the part in the Helping Hands without tightening it too much, and rotated it all around so the metal of the mount smoothed the ball out.
  • Tighten down and use!

description.text: 3d printed telescope built on top of a cardboard tube.

Materials:
-Cardboard tube
-2 small lenses
-Small screw
-Glue Steps:
  • Print both parts
  • Glue 1 lens into each end
  • Cut the tube down to a length close to the focus length of the lenses
  • Press the small lens mount into the end of the tube
  • Slide the second tube onto the cardboard tube
  • Screw the small screw into the cardboard tube near the top of the spiral track
    • Note: I used a tube that was smaller and more rigid than a normal paper towel tube. I recommend using a tube like this if you can find it. If you can't, you'll need to scale up the models.

author: Vasilpap

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kDXDHtNbfk1
This is a Hokey mask.

Got a few spare LED downlights floating around that you want to use as a mini flood light? Grab a few parts and throw one of these together!  
The base has a thread and a nut over it, which holds the legs in either the open or folded position.  
Simply undo the nut, fold the legs down or up, and tighten the nut in place.

Non printed parts: 1x LED Downlight - Do not use anything other than a low wattage LED, or you will probably melt your plastic ;)
1x 16mm dowel rod - 350mm long
1x 12v battery - I use my 3S lipos with a low voltage buzzer on the balance plug
1x cable to connect the downlight to a battery, you'd be looking for something with an MR16 connector on one end, and you'd need to solder an appropriate connector on the other end for your battery.
2x cable ties
5x M4 nuts
3x 25mm M4 screws
2x 20mm M4 screws
1x short wood screw Printed parts:
1x Light Tower Base
1x Light Tower Nut
3x Light Tower Legs 1x Light Tower Holder and Hinge (if you want to use a downlight) If you find that the downlight holder in the above STL is too small, print the 'holder only' STL. It has a bit more space, but may be a little too loose depending on how well calibrated your printer is. I've got it all! Now what?

  • Jam the dowel down into the base as tight as you can. The hole is tapered, so it should jam in no problem, if not, put a bit of glue in the hole with it.

  • Push a leg into one of the holes, ensuring the tapered section is facing outwards (this means it should sit on the floor more evenly when it is deployed).

  • Push an M4 nut into a hole for that leg, they are quite tight, so if it doesnt quite fit, dont be too fussed. Push a 25mm M4 screw through the hole and tighten it up. If the nut didn't push into the hole, make sure the nut is aligned properly with the hole and tighten the screw up. It should pull in no worries.

  • Repeat steps 2 and 3 for the other two legs.

  • Screw the nut onto the base with the legs folded down. You will find that they can't fold up anymore. Neat huh?

  • Push the two final M4 nuts into the lower part of the downlight holder. As in step 3, if they dont push in easily, tighten a screw up in it, and it will pull the nut into place.

  • Put the downlight into the upper half of the downlight holder. It will be easier to put the light in now before attaching it to the other downlight part, as it should be a little bit flexible.

  • Drill a hole into the end of the dowel, and screw the downlight holder into place with your wood screw.

  • Screw the upper half of the downlight holder into the lower half.

  • Attach your cable to the pole with your two cable ties, ensuring you have enough space at the top so you can rotate your lamp around without putting too much strain on your cable.
    • And you are done!! I created this part using OpenSCAD, but unfortunately I have lost the code for the top part. If there is enough demand, I will recreate it and post it up. I used syvwlch's thread library, but i really didn't do a great job of utilising it! I didn't spend much time playing with it... Sorry!

A battery adapter to replace expensive sold-in Lion batteries to replaceable common 18650 batteries without any changes at your Trail Camera.
I used a 2x 18650 battery box from supplier www.buyincoins.com.
http://www.buyincoins.com/item/9160.html#.VZFS40atEmU

Print the STL-File, solder the two wires to the small PCB or connector, glue the 18650 box to the new battery case. Ready!
May you can use the old PCB from defective battery pack for your new one too.

http://www.buyincoins.com/item/217.html#.VZFW2katEmU

Have fun and great pictures...

This is a survivor/zombivor card holder for zombicide season 1 (may work with other seasons).
It prevents the 5 cards to move every time you need to add 1 XP. It happens to me all the time and it's sometime hard to replace the cards as they were before they get dropped.
2 versions :

  • The double one covers both side (survivor/zombivor) at the same time.
    -The single one covers only one side, two singles can be used at the same time (it's the double one splitted in two parts).
    WARNING : Scratch may appear while you're inserting it on your card. Do not use if your print quality isn't good enough and/or if your cards are collector.
    UPDATE : A version for sleeved card had been added ( 2 mm extra width) : It SHOULD fit, but as my cards are not sleeved, I can't test it. So, don't blame me if it's not ok. I'll appreciate your feedback.

Support de carte pour survivant/zombivant pour Zombicide saison 1 (et les autres saisosn, je suppose).
Ce support empêche les cartes équipement de bouger/tomber chaque fois que vous vous rajoutez un point d'expérience.
2 versions :
-La première est double (les deux cotés de la carte en même temps.
-La version simple ne couvre qu'un seul coté. 2 versions simples peuvent être utilisées en même temps (c'est la version double coupée en deux).
ATTENTION : La carte survivant peut légèrement s'abimer lors de l'insertion si la qualité d'impression n'est pas suffisante. Ne pas utiliser si la qualité d'impression et/ou si vous êtes collectionneur.

UPDATE : Une version pour carte protégée est disponible (2 mm de plus en largeur). Elle DEVRAIT fonctionner, mais je ne peux pas en être sûr car mes cartes ne sont pas protégées. Ne m'en veuillez donc pas si cela ne fait pas l'affaire. Merci de me faire un retour sur cette version.

Printed on Ultimaker 2
0.2 mm layer
2400 mm/mn
PLA 205°C
3 pieces printed at once to get clean results.
No support needed on UM2

Feel free to try other settings. I'm pretty sure that my print quality is not at it's best (I'm aware about printing at 0.1 mm layer, but I'm looking for the best result at 0.2 mm for now).
Some cleaning may have to be done on the printed part, but no big deal (a couple of minutes with a thin knife).

Simplified, FDM 3D printable ATLAS model
Based on the ATLAS TDR:s from mid 1990:s

From http://atlas.ch/ :
"ATLAS is a particle physics experiment at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN that is searching for new discoveries in the head-on collisions of protons of extraordinarily high energy."

Written by Henrik Åkerstedt (Stockholm University)
with invaluable assistance from Sam Silverstein

Use Customizer to enable/disable specific parts.
The "General" tab includes a Print Flag that needs to be on, as well as a Cut flag that will enable/disable wedges cut out from the model.

It is recommended to print e.g. the opposing extended tile barrels with one plain version and one cut version.

On the "General" tab, targe-scale structures can be enabled/disabled. Each sub-detector can be enabled/disabled on its own tab.

Separate STL files also available. Print every part once, except:
Feet (print twice)
Choose between realistic (Barrel_Fixed.stl) or extractable (Barrel.stl)
Choose between full toroid (Toroid.stl) or cutout version (Toroid_Cut)

LarTileB needs support to print properly, all muon barrels and the toroid system needs a bottom brim to print reliably.
The small and large outer wheel needs to be glued together, as well as the feet (they sort of friction-fit, but easily come off unless glued).

The muon parts look great in translucent plastic. Magnets (Toroid and EndCaps) and Feet should be gray.

The order in which the parts appear in the gallery is roughly the assembly order.

Hope you like it!

description.text:
This light sculpture illuminates pi, a number that has brought enlightenment to students and scholars of math and science throughout the ages.

A mathematical technique warps the cutouts on the curved sides of the cylinder such that an unwarped shadow is cast on the floor. The digits of pi swirl along the arm of an Archimedes spiral; the length of the sequence before it fades a measure of your printer's ability to capture fine details.

This project involves soldering, small-parts, electrical components and an extremely bright LED. You assume all risks and liabilities should you wish to undertake it.

Print it:

The lamp consists of two parts, a base and a lid. The cutouts on the base are larger towards the bottom of the lamp and get smaller further up. Because of this, you should get a good print regardless of the resolution of your printer -- a high resolution print will extend length of the sequence that is legible, but is not necessary.

I made my print on a consumer FDM printer at 0.16mm layer height and retraction enabled

Light it up:

I used a 20mm high-power green LED star for my build. A pack of ten costs about $5 on eBay. The LED is rated at up to 3W. I've found running it at around half that seems to give good results without overheating and without needing a heat sink.

Be careful not to look directly at the LED. It is extremely bright and could damage your eyes.

Power it:

A green high-power LED star will run off 2.2-3.4V, so you will need a suitable power supply. I used a bench-top adjustable power supply for testing, but in my final build I used a recycled 12V wall wart combined with a adjustable micro DC-DC step-down converter from e-bay. The particular one I used was listed as "10pcs Mini DC-DC Converter Step Down Module Adjustable Output 1-17V for RC PLANE" and sold by axeprice. It was small enough to fit inside the lamp, but you could also mount a larger module outside of the lamp. The converter has an adjustable output voltage, so you can tune the brightness of the LED and balance it against heat output.

You could also get fairly good results with a two AA batteries and maybe some resistors, but it would not run as long.

Choosing the correct voltage:

Because in my build I did not use resistors, picking the correct voltage for the LED is very critical. The LED will begin conducting at a certain voltage, but beyond that, the current will increase very sharply. The sweet spot is only a few tenths of a volt beyond the initial conduction point. I recommend using a bench-top power supply with a variable voltage knob and an integrated ammeter to determine the voltage that causes enough current to run through the LED without overheating (about 0.4A for a 3W LED). Once you have determined the correct voltage, re-check it using a multimeter and write it down. You will use this voltage to tune the DC-to-DC converter during assembly.

Assemble it:

Assembly consists of soldering the various parts together. Be very careful about the polarity of the components. The following build sequence worked for me:

  • Cut the plug off your AC wall wart and separate the two wires to give a slack of about six inches.
  • Feed the two wires through the guide holes on the lid to the other side.
  • Solder the wires to the input pads of your DC-to-DC converter (In+ and In-). Use a multimeter to determine which wire is positive and which is negative if you cannot tell. Polarity is very important.
  • Plug in the AC wall wart and using the multimeter adjust the voltage on your DC-to-DC converter to the value you determined above. If you do not have a multimeter, set it to 2.3V to start -- this will keep you from blowing out your LED when you first power it up.
  • Solder two short lengths of wire to the LED + and - pads. A set of bench top helping hands is very good for this task.
  • Solder the other end of the wires to the output terminals of the DC-to-DC converter. Mind the polarity -- if you get it reversed, the LED will not light.
  • Use double sided foam tape to stick the DC-to-DC converter and the LED to the inside of the lid. The LED needs to be perfectly centered for the shadows to cast correctly.

Tune it:

Once you first plug it in, run your lamp without the base attached and monitor it to make sure the LED is not getting too hot. Let it run a couple minutes and checking regularly to make sure that it is not getting too hot to the touch. If it is, dial back the voltage on the DC-to-DC converter.

You want the LED to run warm, but not hot enough to melt the plastic or cause a fire hazard. Do not run the lamp unattended until you have monitored it for several hours to make sure heat is not a problem.

Customize it:

This design is fully customizable. Be sure to check it out in the Makerbot customizer!

Credits and Inspiration:

  • The idea of depicting PI in a spiral came from "Tower of Pi" by Roman Hegglin
  • Inspired by stereographic projection ideas of Henry Segerman and Saul Schleimer

comments.text: This is just too cool.  What affects how blurry the numbers get the further away from the floor/wall the lamp is?  Or more importantly, what can I do to print one that would look good from further away?  Thicker walls, more infill, better printer?
comments.author: wifibum

comments.text: The size of the LED plays a part. The smaller it is, the sharper the shadow it will cast. You can probably help make it sharper with thicker walls.
comments.author: wifibum

comments.text: Also, how reflective the material is. You want all the light coming from a point, the less bouncing around inside the lamp the better. So a black, matte filament would be better than a light color, glossy one.

This Printrbot Jr. Bowden extruder mod will remove the heavy extruder (cold-end) from the Printrbot Jr printing head. This will significantly reduce the moving mass of the printer. Resulting in far less vibrations, higher printing speeds and a major improvement in printing quality.

The parts are designed to use with stock printrbot jr bolts and nuts. Parts needed:
-Approx. 50 cm PFTE tubing 2mm x 4mm
http://reprapworld.com/?products_details&products_id=167&cPath=1616_1653
-2x Pneufit straight adaptor,1/8in x 4mm
http://reprapworld.com/?products_details&products_id=169&cPath=1616_1653 Note: the pneufit adaptors may cause backlash / oozing due to their ability to extend. This can be fixed by e.g.: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:98858

comments.text: That's a good idea too. I figured that you could mount the extruder on the body of the Jr and then draw filament from the bottom of the spool with the spool on the same level as the printer, rather than drawing it from the top of the spool with the spool elevated with respect to the printer, as most people do. As you say, you could integrate the extruder motor into the spool support base instead. Simple nozzle holder for the Prusa i3 Steel. It's designed to lock into any 3mm wall of the frame, and can hold up to 9 nozzles.

Portaboquillas simple para la Prusa i3 Steel. Fue diseñado para encajar en cualquier pared de 3mm del marco, y puede almacenar hasta 9 boquillas.

I printed it with no support, using a 0.5mm nozzle and 0.25mm layer height. You can probably tweak these values to get a nicer result.

Lo imprimí sin soportes, con una boquilla de 0.5mm y con alto de capa de 0.25mm. Se pueden modificar estos valores para obtener mejores resultados.

title: Prusa Air 2 Gecko by ChaosModder (with all components)

description.text:
Hi Guys,

I have my Prusa Air 2 Remix uploaded. It is currently not ready yet so please do not be surprised if I do change something. Preliminary a thank you to the other who the Prusa Air 2 designed and improved. I've taken a few components, make it easier to print the Prusa Air 2 Gecko. Of the components that I have used I will always refer to the source. Should anyone disturbing that I have the parts here announces you please. Moreover, I could not find the source of Thigiverse Motor Holder of the Z axis. If I have overlooked you, write me!

Why did I call him Prusa Air 2 Gecko?

I have read the submission from Prusa Air 2 and this adapted to my
terrarium of Exo Terra. I once bred geckos and had to give reasons for this time. As a souvenir of the geckos to this 3D printer myself commemorated at her. The colors I have therefore chosen as the Grandi (much green, red, something orange and turquoise). The terrarium is to prevent the dust / fumes outlet. To make this possible I bought filter. I want after the joyriding The Lizard, Prusa Pimp (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26609) adapt to this project.

What have I done?

First, I have looked at several 3D printer. The models that were I liked best the Prusa Air models. Then I looked what versions there. I have taken as a template to Prusa Air 2.

The sizes are almost identical to the Prusa Air 2 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14204). As can be seen in the pictures, I have the printer built so that it can be placed in an Exo Terra terarium (45cm x 45cm x 60cm).

The components are labeled "P01_1pic_Name.stl" that the first compartment of which part number is P01 = Part01. The second part tells how many times you need the component 1pic = 1 piece. The third part is the name of the component.

The DXF file has been processed by Prusa Air 2 that the Motor holder on Z axis can be mounted. In addition, a stabilization in the back of Additional Services was installed. There were introduced with holes for "Arduino Mega".
The X axis holder of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18384 I have in the metric trapezoidal leadscrews TR8x1.5 and nuts of 17mm wrench size (15mm height) version uses. It can also be used the other version of it. The acrylic glass is 6mm thickness. I let the acrylic laser cutting.

Currently going some remodeling and have decided on a Bulldog extruder (http://www.reprapdiscount.com/), a metal carriage (http://reprapworld.com/?products_details&products_id/599/cPath/1616_1668#.VZFMnrQu9hE) and a "Reprap Mendel Prusa i3 Z Axis Y Carriage Plate timing Belt Holder Aluminum Alloy" on ebay. Still useable, the 3D printers are constructed with the selected parts.

I will keep you updated about new changes to date. I hope you like it.

title: Bre Pettis OpenSCAD Medal, Now With Text

description.text: The Bre Pettis Medal looked a little forlorn without some text around the edge... so I grabbed grokbeer's MakerBot Font module, and whipped up a little addition to the medal script. The font module: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6844

You need to define the text as an array of one-element arrays, so that each individual letter can be rotated into position around the edge of the medal.
There is also a matching kerning array which allows you to fine-tune the distance between each letter, because the default spacing doesn't look that great.
This script and method are public domain, but they use grokbeer's font module which is not.

title: Self-Watering Planter (Small)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Introducing the first design from Parallel Goods.

This Self-Watering Planter is exactly the growing environment your plants need, while giving you flexibility in your watering routine. It’s super easy to use: just plant your favorite herb or other water-intensive plant, add water, and you’re all set.

The Self-Watering Planter was designed to be 3D printed, easy to setup, use and clean; while at the same time allow for customization through mixing and matching different colors for the pot and reservoir. Be sure to check out the Instructions tab to make sure you get the most out this Self-Watering Planter.

This Self-Watering Planter is part of our 2015 Desk Collection, with more great designs available at parallelgoods.co.

Follow us on Thingiverse, join our Thingiverse Group, and follow us on Twitter and Instagram @parallelgoods and stay tuned!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

This Self-Watering Planter was design to be printed in PLA, and we went through many iterations and lots of experimentation to develop settings which would allow for a water tight print. All of our testing and development was done in PLA to ensure success across a wide variety of printers, without causing too much of an impact to the environment.

Water Tight PLA Slic3r Settings

  • Layer Height: .3mm
  • Vertical Shells (Perimeters): 3
  • Horizontal Shells (Solid Layers): Top – 4, Bottom – 4
  • Infill: 10% - Speed: Top Solid Infill – 15mm/s, Solid infill – 15mm/s
  • Prints WITHOUT Supports

The extra top & bottom shells combined with the slow solid infill print speeds ensure a thick and even wall for the bottom of the reservoir which provides water tight print. Your mileage may vary, but these settings should give you a fine starting point for use on your own printer.

If you're unable to get a water tight print...

If you're unable to get a water tight print, we recommend coating the bottom of the reservoir in Titebond-3 Wood Glue. This particular wood glue is waterproof, but still non-toxic, solvent free, and is FDA approved for indirect food contact (i.e. cutting boards).

Using your Self-Watering Planter

Set the pot in the reservoir, add your plant of choice, and fill the reservoir to the line inside of the spout. Refill whenever you can’t see any water in the spout. Every few cycles it’s helpful to let the soil dry out to prevent mold from growing inside the pot.

You can find the larger version of our planter pictured here at http://parallelgoods.co

comments.text: We choose to work with PLA so a wider range of printer owners would be able to print our designs. While PLA is biodegradable it is not water soluble, so using it for a planter should be just fine. We've got planters printed in PLA that are over two years old at this point and still entirely water tight.
comments.author: Complex

comments.text:
I posted a photo of my print. The concern is not about leaking... PLA will not host bacteria but it can be attacked by bacteria products and decompose. In the professional environment, indoor potting soil is usually sterilized so that is probably not a big deal. But if someone just pick up some yard soil and left it in a PLA pot for years, funny things can happen......
The pot have a pretty small footprint, and it is a circle without corners, so experienced "3D printer operator" can usually pull it out even their printers does not have heated bed.

comments.text: It sounds like it could be one of two things. Either the part is too big for your printer (even after scaling it down), or slic3r isn't finishing the slicing operation all the way. Try opening the gcode file in a text editor and scrolling all the way to the bottom of the file and see if the end gcode that slic3r adds is in the file. If the end gcode from slic3r is in the file, then it's probably just the part being too big for your printer.

This is a nifty little case for your AVR pocket programmer. Unlike many of the things out there, this one is 100% 3D printed.

The top shell allows for access of the AVR programming cable, while the bottom shell holds the board firmly without screws or mounting hardware. The two shells snap tightly together.

Assembly note: I printed both shells using a Makerbot replicator 2 using the High quality settings (0.1mm resolution and no rafts). The design includes supports for the board clips, which can be removed easily with either a flat blade screwdriver or hobby knife.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/i8gPyMYDuAO

Here's a video of it in action...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rwvbkn8xL6A&feature=youtu.be

Here's a group I made for my LED lights and things, if you like my LED designs, join the group and you'll be updated as I upload new ones... I plan on making a lot more logos just like this. So if you have and suggestions, please tell me and I'll make it.

http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/things-with-leds/things

This is a extruded LED Makerbot logo I printed on my dual extruder... I took a JPEG of the Makerbot logo and traced it in Solidworks... I then extruded and filleted the logo and saved it as its own STL to be used in dual extrusion... I then designed a plate around the logo, added holes for screws and save that as its own STL... Lastly, I design a shell to go around the plate and logo, the shell has aligned screw holes so it can be fastened to the plate...

I then printed the shell in regular ole black PLA on my Rep 2... And I did the dual extrusion using the same black PLA for the plate and I used Bendlay (link below) to print the logo... I used Bendlay because it is extremely translucent (91% of light passes through)...

I then hooked up an RGB LED strip, wrapped it around the inner shell and hooked it up to an IR receiver so it can be controlled with a remote...

I've also made the following logo's, designs for LED hookup...

This is a extruded LED Android Robot I printed on my dual extruder... I took a JPEG of the Robot and traced it in Solidworks... I then extruded and filleted the robot and saved it as its own STL to be used in dual extrusion... I then designed a plate around the robot, added holes for screws and save that as its own STL... Lastly, I design a shell to go around the plate and robot, the shell has aligned screw holes so it can be fastened to the plate...

I then printed the shell in regular ole black PLA on my Rep 2... And I did the dual extrusion using the same black PLA for the plate and I used Bendlay (link below) to print the robot... I used Bendlay because it is extremely translucent (91% of light passes through)...

I then hooked up an RGB LED strip, wrapped it around the inner shell and hooked it up to an IR receiver so it can be controlled with a remote...

author: thx1313

title: Expandable Rotating Ball Maze
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The concept for this rotating ball maze came to me one day when I was designing some fun objects for visually impaired people to play with.  
By rotating each layer, the holes will align one layer at at time for the ball to go through. There's no way to 'see' which layer the ball is in, so people can only rely on the sound of the ball rolling inside the maze. Both ends of the maze are like cages that have holes small enough to contain the ball inside, but big enough for visually impaired people to feel the ball rolling around.  
As a toy, the goal will be to get the ball from one end to the other end by blindly aligning the layers so the ball can go through.  
This design hasn't been 3D printed and tested yet, but I hope I have made the connectors with the right tolerance so they fit well.

title: Bicycle Front Tire Riser for bicycle trainer stands

description.text:
This is a simple tire riser to be used in conjunction with a bicycle trainer stand. Overall height is 75mm, tallest groove is 50mm, shortest is 25mm. I recently bought a trainer and wanted a riser for the front wheel to level out the bike, but right before I bought one I thought "Hey, I could probably make that". So here it is :D.

I printed this in ABS at 50% infill, 0.25mm layer height and have been using it with good success on the 50mm groove with a Kurt Kinetic trainer.
Hatchbox ABS, 50% infill, 0.25mm layer height.

description.text:
Here's a video of it in action...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9P9R63m4NVA&feature=youtu.be

Here's a group I made for my LED lights and things, if you like my LED designs, join the group and you'll be updated as I upload new ones... I plan on making a lot more logos just like this. So if you have and suggestions, please tell me and I'll make it.

http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/things-with-leds/things

This is a extruded LED Autobot I printed on my dual extruder... I took a JPEG of the logo and traced it in Solidworks... I then extruded and filleted the Autobot and saved it as its own STL to be used in dual extrusion... I then designed a plate around the Autobot, added holes for screws and save that as its own STL... Lastly, I design a shell to go around the plate and Autobot, the shell has aligned screw holes so it can be fastened to the plate...

I then printed the shell in regular ole black PLA on my Rep 2... And I did the dual extrusion using the same black PLA for the plate and I used Bendlay (link below) to print the Autobot... I used Bendlay because it is extremely translucent (91% of light passes through)...

I then hooked up an RGB LED strip, wrapped it around the inner shell and hooked it up to an IR receiver so it can be controlled with a remote...

I've also made the following logo's, designs for LED hookup...

SuperMan: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:905146
StormTrooper: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:905142

I <3 3DPing w/beating heart: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:900678

Bendlay Link:
http://www.amazon.com/MatterHackers-BendLay-Filament-1-75mm-MakerBot/dp/B00K1NRCIY/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1435347958&sr=8-1&keywords=bendlay&pebp=1435347954416&perid=1WG2SRVP9TGP9WAM748W

lightitup

Pretty straight forward, You're going to want to dual extrude the plate and Autobot together... I used PLA Black for the plate and Bendlay for the Autobot due to the fact Bendlay is extremely translucent (91% of light passes through)... But you could use Natural PLA or a translucent filament, but they aren't as translucent as Bendlay is...

I did not print a floor on the plate and Autobot print so it would allow more light to pass through... I did too much infill (10% linear) on mine... I wish I would have done about 5

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8rconngkptt

title: Space Pod from 2001 - A Space Odyssey

description.text: This was an experiment to attempt to directly print 3D files that are used for special effects models and such like. I tried the space pod from http://www.2001-3d-archive.info/, in 3D Studio Max format. I opened it in Meshlab, applied some repairs and simplifications, and scaled it. It does have some funky stuff, there are weird voids and hollows inside, so you have to print with full support, not just external. The experiment was a qualified success. The Thing-O-Matic actually printed everything correctly, but extracting it from the support material was a challenge, especially the very thin and delicate arms. I needed to repair the arms afterwards with Krazy Glue, and they are really super delicate still. I should really just edit the file and print the arms separately. Also worth going over the original file and fixing up a lot of the strangeness.

Don't print it, it's a pain. Much better to actually print the arms separately, and maybe slice the model up so that it can be printed without support material. This might be a good start: http://panocamera.com/blog/?p=290 However, if you do insist on printing it as a single piece, try:
  • small layer height (eg. 0.25mm) for greater resolution
  • use support material
  • make your support material close to the structure (eg. 0.6 filament width)

comments.text: They make you insert a quarter into a shopping cart  and to get it out you must take it to the rest of the carts. it's supposed to keep the prices low because they don't have to hire somebody to gather carts. you just put your quarter in and get it back when you're done shopping and it keeps the parking lots uncluttered and prices low.

remixed_from.author: kencaid
remixed_from.title: Water Meter Wrench, for a 5 sided fastener

title: Water Meter Wrench - 5 Sided, 1" Side to Point

description.text:
This is a wrench for a 5-sided bolt found on common water meter covers. This was remixed from a similar item and changed to fit water meter bolts that measure 1.01" or 25.8mm from any flat side to the opposing point.

If you have a tough bolt an adapter may work better. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:905787

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3RCLhY7bgW8

I printed mine with 3 walls and 35% infill for added strength.
Pretty sure this was overkill, but it's a tool so why not.

Feels very sturdy.

comments.text: These are the 3 sizes one may need.  Great idea to print one.  Looking forward to trying it out.
